title: Level of service Perceptions on campus
description: The project aims to study the relation between objective level of service measures and perceived level of service of cyclists and pedestrian in the university campus (TuDelft) and how this changed in covid-19 times. The project will cary out interviews on campus asking cyclists/pedestrians to evaluate their cyclin/walking experience before and after covid-19 pandemic. We will compare the stated perceptions with the objective measures from campus mobility dashboard such as average flows and densities. Interviews will be conducted in different times of the day (peak and off-peak) so to observe a difference in level of service.

questions.text: What data will you collect or create?

answer.text:
We will collect stated level of service perceptions of cyclists and pedestrians on the TuDelft campus by means of structured interviews. 

This data will be merged with the sensor data collected by the Outdoor Mobility Digital twin (ODMt) in order to have one dataset of objective and subjective mobility level of service measures. The (ODMt) is an ongoing project in TuDelft, developed by the Department of Transport and Planning.

questions.text: How will the data be collected or created?

answer.text:
The stated perception data is manually recorded by means of structured interviews on google or paper forms. The measures of density and flow from the Outdoor Mobility Digital twin (ODMt) are retrived from the API with an aggregation of 60 seconds. 

The data does not have any personal information of the respondents, except for age and gender.

questions.text: What documentation and metadata will accompany the data?

answer.text: Data will be stored as a CSV file and will be accompanied by a readme file explaining each feature and how it has been collected.

questions.text: How will you manage any ethical issues?

answer.text:
The identity of the participants is protected by anonymized interviews. We do not ask name, campus cards, Id etc.  We only ask for age and gender.

We will ask the respondents to use their anonymized data for research purposes via an informed consent form.

questions.text: How will you manage copyright and Intellectual Property Rights (IPR) issues?

answer.text: Giulia Reggiani will own the data from the interviews on campus.

questions.text: How will the data be stored and backed up during the research?

answer.text:
The data is first collected manually, on paper or google forms.

During the analysis, the data will be stored locally on Giulia Reggiani's TuDelft computer and her surf-drive account.

questions.text: How will you manage access and security?

answer.text: Giulia and her supervision team,  prof. Serge Hoogendoorn and prof. Winnie Daamen, will have access to the data in the first phase during the execution of the data analysis. Data is not confidential, thus we do not foresee security risks.

questions.text: Which data are of long-term value and should be retained, shared, and/or preserved?

answer.text: Data will be retained at least up until 4 years after the research is conducted. This is to guarantee validation of the findings and future research to follow. For preservation reasons we will upload the data to the TuDelft online repository (or Giulia Reggiani's GitHub page) once it has been cleaned and processed.

questions.text: What is the long-term preservation plan for the dataset?

answer.text: Data will be preserved and made available to peers on an online repository.

questions.text: How will you share the data?

answer.text: Data will be available on the online repositories after the study has been conducted and a publication is submitted to a peer-review journal. Any researcher willing to use the data can do so by downloading it from the repository and citing our work.

questions.text: Are any restrictions on data sharing required?

answer.text: NO

questions.text: Who will be responsible for data management?

answer.text: Giulia Reggiani is responsible for the entire data management pipeline.

questions.text: What resources will you require to deliver your plan?

answer.text: None

title: Multimodal learning analytics for sustained attention
description: We will study sustained attention in the remote learning context by collecting data from different sensors (webcam facing participant, mobile phone sensors, smartwatch sensors, (external) microphone(s), body temperature sensor) while participants perform a learning task. The study is expected to include around 10 participants including the researchers themselves and possibly other students, all under the young adults without comorbidity group and one participant at a time. During the learning task, the experimenters may introduce distracting stimuli such as background noises in order to trigger a distraction. Throughout the study, we will comply with RIVM-guidelines to prevent the spread of the COVID-19 disease. Everyone will keep appropriate distance, wear a face mask when not seated and we will clean all equipment in between participants.

questions.text: What data will you collect or create?

answer.text:
• webcam video facing participant
  • mobile phone movement including accelerometer, gyroscope and microphone
  • smartwatch movement including accelerometer and gyroscope
  • (external) microphone(s), recording ambient sound
  • body temperature sensor, taking participants temperature

questions.text: How will the data be collected or created?

answer.text:
Data will be collected using:

  • a webcam facing participant
  • mobile phone movement including accelerometer, gyroscope and microphone
  • smartwatch movement including accelerometer and gyroscope
  • (external) microphone(s), recording ambient sound
  • body temperature sensor, taking participants temperature

title: Pranvi's Plan
description:
Mission-oriented Innovation Policies (MIP) are a powerful tool to drive innovative transformation that is associated with technological breakthroughs across socio-technical systems and address societal and environmental challenges. These policies are driven by normative or political goals and differ from the traditional market failure approach that focuses on economic growth and fail to address the societal challenges. Innovation finds its true purpose in the hands of consumers and the relationship between consumers and missions is crucial for the longevity contribution to the success of the innovation. For the mission-oriented approach to tackle a challenge and for innovation to make an impact in society, demand for innovation is necessary. However, the existence of policies in the system does not ensure demand articulation, although it claims to tackle the challenge. The aspect of demand articulation has been introduced in the research, to emphasize on the need to investigate the barriers for consumption, as consumption is linked to demand. Therefore, it is important to understand consumption to explain demand articulation failures (i.e., the absence of demand) in transitions.
The research is designed to add relevance to the Mission Oriented Innovation System by diving into the case of the Dutch fashion industry and drawing insights from the case. The industry is an example of a socio-technical system that is in transition to Circular Economy (CE). There exist Mission-Oriented Innovation Policies to reach 100% circularity in the Dutch industry by 2050. Therefore, there is a need to understand what impedes consumption to better understand what impedes demand. This will be done by means of analyzing the barriers for consumption that individuals encounter, as no previous study in the context of transitions has been done. 
To achieve sustainable development, sustainable consumption is an important aspect apart from efforts made on cleaner production. Sustainable consumption is constituted by buyer behavior, values and motivation towards eco-friendly products that result in less pollution during pollution. Although consumers are environmentally aware of their purchases, it is not in line with the actual market share of sustainable clothes. The increased awareness and consciousness of sustainability had a limited impact in forming purchasing decisions.
For a transition to a circular economy in the fashion industry, demand for sustainable and circular products is required. However, to create the societal demand, identifying factors affecting individual the consumption would be beneficial. However, when we look at the literature, we observe a lack of literature on consumer behavior and usage of CE business models, despite the presence of demand-side policies thereby leading to absence of demand or demand articulation failure. To solve demand articulation failures in the industry, it is crucial to identify what barriers form its root cause, as this forms important input for innovation policy. The root cause of demand articulation failures in transitions has been very little studied. It is not known what micro-level factors impede the micro-level consumption that constitutes the macro-level consumer demand. As these micro-consumption factors are not known, policies might not be effective to create demand.
The research focuses on the fashion industry, which is a demand-driven industry. Currently, the lack of circular fashion demand is a barrier towards the implementation of circular business models. Based on the research gap identified, the objective of the research is to better understand the demand articulation failure using the case-study of Dutch fashion industry that is undergoing CE transition. Despite the efforts to produce sustainable clothes, the fashion industries promoting circularity relatively make up a very small segment of the market. The study aims to identify and analyze factors influencing circular clothing consumption among Dutch consumers. Once the micro-factors obstructing the consumption behavior are identified, the factors could explain macro-level demand articulation failures. These factors would be an important input for the existing sustainable and/or circular policies in the clothing industry. This would help the policymakers to address and analyze these factors and further speed up the CE transition in the fashion industry.

questions.text: What data will you collect or create?

answer.text: A qualitative approach is used for the research. Initially, as a part of the research critical literature review will be conducted by going through books, journals, conference papers, Ph.D. theses. For rigor, primary sources of data collection in the form of interviews would be used. These interviews will be conducted virtually

title: Procurement of diagnostic equipment in Dutch hospitals - policy

template.title: TU Delft Data Management Plan template (2021)

description: Health care technology management (HTM) is essential to create strong, resilient health systems. Procurement is a crucial aspect of HTM, resulting in timeliness and costs of delivered health care and ultimately health system performance. This study is meant to break down the procurement process of high tech diagnostic equipment in Dutch hospitals and identify policy interventions with a positive impact on procurement effectiveness. Apart from literature research, domain experts and stakeholders will be consulted to conceptualize and verify an conceptual model and an agent based model and to give insight in potential policy interventions. Policy interventions based on foreign countries (literature) and expert input will be simulated to finally give a policy advice to benefit procurement effectiveness.

plan_content.title: TU Delft Data Management Plan
plan_content.description:
This is the TU Delft Data Management Plan template. You should fill in this template if any of the following are met:

  • You are funded by NWO or ZonMw (NWO and ZonMw approved TU Delft's template for their DMP requirement)
  • You are working with personal research data
  • You need a data management plan as part of your PhD project
  • You are not funded by a third party, or that third party has no templates for a DMP

For questions about data management plans, please contact your Faculty Data Steward.

questions.text: 1. Name of data management support staff consulted during the preparation of this plan.

answer.text: Nicolas Dintzner

questions.text: 2. Date of consultation with support staff.

sections.title: I. Data description and collection or re-use of existing data

questions.text: 3. Provide a general description of the type of data you will be working with, including any re-used data:

answer.text:
Type of data File format(s) How will data be collected (for re-used data: source and terms of use)? Purpose of processing Storage location Who will have access to the data
Self-built models .py Software Build decision models Gitlab (TUDelft) Researcher, supervisor, advisor (Saba Hinrichs Krapels and possibly Raphael Klein)
Concept processes .txt (Grey) literature study Build conceptual models SURF drive Researcher, supervisor, advisor (Saba Hinrichs Krapels and possibly Raphael Klein)
Current DM processes .txt Professional interviews Structure models SURF drive Researcher, supervisor, advisor (Saba Hinrichs Krapels and possibly Raphael Klein)
(optional) procurement/HTA best practices (international perspective) .csv Survey Background info, discussion of position in field SURF drive Researcher, supervisor, advisor (Saba Hinrichs Krapels and possibly Raphael Klein)

questions.text: 4. How much data storage will you require during the project lifetime?
5. What documentation will accompany data?

options.text: README file or other documentation explaining how data is organised

sections.title: III. Storage and backup during research process

questions.text: 6. Where will the data (and code, if applicable) be stored and backed-up during the project lifetime?

answer.text: Only code in Gitlab, rest in SURF

sections.title: IV. Legal and ethical requirements, codes of conduct

questions.text: 7. Does your research involve human subjects?

8A. Will you work with personal data?  (information about an identified or identifiable natural person)

If you are not sure which option to select, ask your Faculty Data Steward for advice. You can also check with the privacy website or contact the privacy team:

8B. Will you work with any types of confidential or classified data or code as listed below? (tick all that apply)

If you are not sure which option to select, ask your Faculty Data Steward for advice.

options.text: No, I will not work with any confidential or classified data/code

questions.text:
9. How will ownership of the data and intellectual property rights to the data be managed?

For projects involving commercially-sensitive research or research involving third parties, seek advice of your Faculty Contract Manager when answering this question. If this is not the case, you can use the example below.

answer.text: The datasets underlying the published papers will be publicly released following the TU Delft Research Data Framework Policy. During the active phase of research, the project leader from TU Delft will oversee the access rights to data (and other outputs), as well as any requests for access from external parties. They will be released publicly no later than at the time of publication of corresponding research papers.

questions.text: 10. Which personal data will you process? Tick all that apply

answer.text: Recordings of interviews

options.text: Photographs, video materials, performance appraisals or student results
Data collected in Informed Consent form (names and email addresses)
Email addresses and/or other addresses for digital communication

questions.text: 11. Please list the categories of data subjects

answer.text: Professionals involved in the decision making process of medical equipment will be interviewed. Those are people working in a hospital of choice.

questions.text: 12. Will you be sharing personal data with individuals/organisations outside of the EEA (European Economic Area)?
13. To which countries will you be transferring personal data:

14. Please contact the privacy team (privacy-tud@tudelft.nl) for advice on data transfer.

Please record below their advice, the data transfer mechanism used and agreed security measures:
15. What is the legal ground for personal data processing?
16. Please describe the informed consent procedure you will follow:

answer.text: All study participants will be asked for their written consent for taking part in the study and for data processing before the start of the interview. This can either be done through a signed document, consent by email, and if that fails extra consent will be asked at the beginning of the audio recording.

questions.text: 17. Where will you store the signed consent forms?

options.text: Same storage solutions as explained in question 6

questions.text:
18. Does the processing of the personal data result in a high risk to the data subjects? 

If the processing of the personal data results in a high risk to the data subjects, it is required to perform a Data Protection Impact Assessment (DPIA). In order to determine if there is a high risk for the data subjects, please check if any of the options below that are applicable to the processing of the personal data during your research (check all that apply).

If two or more of the options listed below apply, you will have to complete the DPIA. Please get in touch with the privacy team: privacy-tud@tudelft.nl to receive support with DPIA.
If only one of the options listed below applies, your project might need a DPIA. Please get in touch with the privacy team: privacy-tud@tudelft.nl to get advice as to whether DPIA is necessary.

If you have any additional comments, please add them in the box below.
19. Did the privacy team advise you to perform a DPIA?
20. Please include below the outcome of the DPIA, what measures did you take?
21. Where will you store the DPIA documents (document on data processing features and document on risk assessment)?
22. What will happen with personal research data after the end of the research project?

answer.text: AV recording will be destroyed

options.text: Personal research data will be destroyed after the end of the research project
Anonymised or aggregated data will be shared with others

questions.text: 23. How long will (pseudonymised) personal data be stored for?

options.text: 10 years or more, in accordance with the TU Delft Research Data Framework Policy

questions.text: 24. What is the purpose of sharing personal data?

answer.text: Only pseumdonimised/aggregated data will be shared

options.text: For research purposes, which are in-line with the original research purpose for which data have been collected

questions.text: 25. Will your study participants be asked for their consent for data sharing?

answer.text: Participants are asked for full consent before interview planning. When someone does not with to participate under the set conditions, no data is collected. When a participant changes their mind the data should be destroyed.

options.text: Yes, in consent form - please explain below what will do with data from participants who did not consent to data sharing

options.text: All data (and code) produced in the project

questions.text: 27. Apart from personal data mentioned in question 22, will any other data be publicly shared?

options.text: All other non-personal data (and code) underlying published articles / reports / theses

questions.text: 28. How will you share your research data (and code)?
29. How will you share research data (and code), including the one mentioned in question 22?

answer.text: A Gitlab snapshot will be uploaded to 4TU after the project

options.text: All anonymised or aggregated data, and/or all other non-personal data will be uploaded to 4TU.ResearchData with public access

questions.text: 30. How much of your data will be shared in a research data repository?
31. When will the data (or code) be shared?

options.text: At the end of the research project

questions.text: 32. Under what licence will be the data/code released?

answer.text:
BSD3

 

CC BY-ND is ticked for cases if and only if participants only want to share certain information under the condition of this stricter license.

34. If you leave TU Delft (or are unavailable), who is going to be responsible for the data resulting from this project?

answer.text: Saba Hinrichs-Krapels

answer.text: Resrouces currently available will be sufficient for this project.

plan_content.title: NWO Data Management Plan (September 2020)
plan_content.description:
This template is intended for creating a data management plan, based on the data management section that was part of your research proposal. NWO expects you to incorporate any comments received from the referees and/or the committee about the data management section in this data management plan.

You are expected to consult with research data management support staff at your home institution for the completion of this plan. NWO strongly advises researchers to seek such support at an early stage. Plans that have not been consulted with institutional data management support staff will not be accepted.

What does NWO understand as research data?

Research data are the evidence that underpin the answer to research questions, and can be used to validate findings. Data can be quantitative information or qualitative statements collected by researchers in the course of their work by experimentation, observation, modelling, interview or other methods, or information derived from existing evidence.

For the purpose of NWO’s data management policy, the definition of research data does not include physical objects such as scientific and archaeological collections, physical arts works or biobanks; however, digital information extracted from such objects are to be regarded as research data.

Software is also not included in the definition. NWO recognizes that software (algorithms, scripts and code developed by researchers in the course of their work) may be necessary to access and interpret data. In such cases, the data management plan will be expected to address how information about such items will be made available.

How to submit this template?

Your are kindly requested to complete the plan and submit it to NWO within four months after the grant was awarded. As soon as the data management plan has been approved by NWO the project can be started. The plan can be completed in Dutch.

The completed form is to be submitted via the online application system ISAAC. Data management plans not submitted via ISAAC will not be taken into consideration. The plan can be completed in Dutch.

It is advised to regularly review the data management plan when required by the course of the research project and keep it a 'living document'.

questions.text: Name applicant and project number
Name of data management support staff consulted during the preparation of this plan and date of consultation.

sections.title: 1. What data will be collected or produced, and what existing data will be re-used?

questions.text:
1.1 Will you re-use existing data for this research?

If yes: explain which existing data you will re-use and under which terms of use.
1.2 If new data will be produced: describe the data you expect your research will generate and the format and volumes to be collected or produced.
1.3. How much data storage will your project require in total?

sections.title: 2. What metadata and documentation will accompany the data?

questions.text: 2.1 Indicate what documentation will accompany the data.
2.2 Indicate which metadata will be provided to help others identify and discover the data.

sections.title: 3. How will data and metadata be stored and backed up during the research?

questions.text: 3.1 Describe where the data and metadata will be stored and backed up during the project.
3.2 How will data security and protection of sensitive data be taken care of during the research?

sections.title: 4. How will you handle issues regarding the processing of personal information and intellectual property rights and ownership?

questions.text:
4.1 Will you process and/or store personal data during your project?

If yes, how will compliance with legislation and (institutional) regulation on personal data be ensured?
4.2 How will ownership of the data and intellectual property rights to the data be managed?

sections.title: 5. How and when will data be shared and preserved for the long term?

questions.text: 5.1 How will data be selected for long-term preservation?

5.2 Are there any (legal, IP, privacy related, security related) reasons to restrict access to the data once made publicly available, to limit which data will be made publicly available, or to not make part of the data publicly available?

If yes, please explain.
5.3 What data will be made available for re-use?
5.4 When will the data be available for re-use, and for how long will the data be available?
5.5 In which repository will the data be archived and made available for re-use, and under which license?
5.6 Describe your strategy for publishing the analysis software that will be generated in this project.
6.1 What resources (for example financial and time) will be dedicated to data management and ensuring that data will be FAIR (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, Re-usable)?

title: Microfluidic extraction
description:
The goal of the proposed research is to develop a microfluidic liquid-liquid extraction chip that ensures fast
purification during the production of relevant medical radioisotopes. Chemical separation methods
will be optimized or developed and a comparison will be made between microfluidic and conventional
separation efficiency by using radiation detection and ICP-OES. Factors such as mutual solubility of solvents
and metal salt concentration will be investigated thoroughly. Initially, commercially available microfluidic
chips (e.g. glass YY-systems) will be used to investigate low radioactive solutions, but the switch to the
microfluidic chips developed in this project will be made as soon as these are available.Ideally, the unused target
material can directly be recycled for irradiation. If traces of other compounds are present, however,
unwanted by-products can be formed during irradiation. To this purpose, analytic methods need to be
determined (i.e. mass spectrometry, gas or liquid chromatography) that detect the presence of
contaminants after the purification step. In the case of contaminations, the extraction method must be
adjusted, e.g. by varying the organic solvent, the extractants or pH.After purification, the radioisotopes need to be dissolved into a
solvent matrix (aqueous medium, specified pH, acceptable buffer system) required by the clinic. This can
be done e.g. by solid phase extraction or back extraction. In this respect, quality control protocols for all
isotopes need to be developed. The objective is to investigate the applicability of the newly developed microfluidic chip to the two most
applied irradiation systems for medical isotopes, being the nuclear reactor and the cyclotron. Instead of
feeding single, premade radioisotopes to the microfluidic chip, irradiated liquid target material will be fed to the chips. These targets contain by-products, e.g. by radiolysis during irradiation.

plan_content.title: NWO Data Management Plan (September 2020)
plan_content.description:
This template is intended for creating a data management plan, based on the data management section that was part of your research proposal. NWO expects you to incorporate any comments received from the referees and/or the committee about the data management section in this data management plan.

You are expected to consult with research data management support staff at your home institution for the completion of this plan. NWO strongly advises researchers to seek such support at an early stage. Plans that have not been consulted with institutional data management support staff will not be accepted.

What does NWO understand as research data?

Research data are the evidence that underpin the answer to research questions, and can be used to validate findings. Data can be quantitative information or qualitative statements collected by researchers in the course of their work by experimentation, observation, modelling, interview or other methods, or information derived from existing evidence.

For the purpose of NWO’s data management policy, the definition of research data does not include physical objects such as scientific and archaeological collections, physical arts works or biobanks; however, digital information extracted from such objects are to be regarded as research data.

Software is also not included in the definition. NWO recognizes that software (algorithms, scripts and code developed by researchers in the course of their work) may be necessary to access and interpret data. In such cases, the data management plan will be expected to address how information about such items will be made available.

How to submit this template?

Your are kindly requested to complete the plan and submit it to NWO within four months after the grant was awarded. As soon as the data management plan has been approved by NWO the project can be started. The plan can be completed in Dutch.

The completed form is to be submitted via the online application system ISAAC. Data management plans not submitted via ISAAC will not be taken into consideration. The plan can be completed in Dutch.

It is advised to regularly review the data management plan when required by the course of the research project and keep it a 'living document'.

questions.text: Name applicant and project number
Name of data management support staff consulted during the preparation of this plan and date of consultation.

sections.title: 1. What data will be collected or produced, and what existing data will be re-used?

questions.text:

If yes: explain which existing data you will re-use and under which terms of use.
1.2 If new data will be produced: describe the data you expect your research will generate and the format and volumes to be collected or produced.

answer.text: The new data produced will be ICP or radiation detection data on phase concentrations. They will be evaluated with excel spreadsheets to calculate efficiencies. These data can be saved as .xls or .csv files. The single sheets only have a size of a few hundred kB and therefore the complete volumen of data produced will most likely not exeed 1GB

questions.text: 2.2 Indicate which metadata will be provided to help others identify and discover the data.

answer.text: Additional metadata information on the experiments will be temperature, time, chemicals, volume ratios etc.

sections.title: 3. How will data and metadata be stored and backed up during the research?

questions.text: 3.1 Describe where the data and metadata will be stored and backed up during the project.

answer.text: My data is saved on a SurfDrive and an external storage unit. Additionally there is a shared SurfDrive, where data, relevant for others in the project, will be stored.

questions.text: 3.2 How will data security and protection of sensitive data be taken care of during the research?

If yes, how will compliance with legislation and (institutional) regulation on personal data be ensured?
4.2 How will ownership of the data and intellectual property rights to the data be managed?

answer.text: Before publication, the NWO and other companies involed have to give their permit for publication.

answer.text: After the project, the data will be stored on the institutional network storage from the supervisors.

questions.text:

If yes, please explain.

answer.text: The experiment set up and all relevant information to repoduce the experiment results will be made public.

questions.text: 5.4 When will the data be available for re-use, and for how long will the data be available?

answer.text: Data needed for reproduction of the resullts will be included in the according publication.

5.6 Describe your strategy for publishing the analysis software that will be generated in this project.
6.1 What resources (for example financial and time) will be dedicated to data management and ensuring that data will be FAIR (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, Re-usable)?

answer.text: No additional costs will be involved.

template.title: TU Delft Data Management Plan template (2021)

plan_content.title: TU Delft Data Management Plan
plan_content.description:
This is the TU Delft Data Management Plan template. You should fill in this template if any of the following are met:

  • You are funded by NWO or ZonMw (NWO and ZonMw approved TU Delft's template for their DMP requirement)
  • You are working with personal research data
  • You need a data management plan as part of your PhD project
  • You are not funded by a third party, or that third party has no templates for a DMP

For questions about data management plans, please contact your Faculty Data Steward.

questions.text: 1. Name of data management support staff consulted during the preparation of this plan.

answer.text: Our faculty data steward, Santosh Ilamparuthi, has reviewed this DMP on xx-xx-xxxx

questions.text: 2. Date of consultation with support staff.

sections.title: I. Data description and collection or re-use of existing data

questions.text: 3. Provide a general description of the type of data you will be working with, including any re-used data:

answer.text:
Type of data File format(s) How will data be collected (for re-used data: source and terms of use)? Purpose of processing Storage location Who will have access to the data
survey data csv, xls Qualtrics (online survey), pen and paper

To collect educational constructs

 Surfdrive, Qualtrics researchers involved in the study
student grades in exam, test, and interactive quizzes csv, xls requested from data coordinators To collect student outcomes Surfdrive researchers involved in the study
log data (e.g., student interaction with the learning materials on the learning management system) csv requested from coordinators of learning management system For data analytics Surfdrive  researchers involved in the study
audio and video recordings mp4, mp3 teams, zoom, recording platform To conduct qualitative interviews  Surfdrive, atlas.ti, NVivo, Dedoose  researchers involved in the study
text and images type data  .txt, .gif, .png miro, mural To collect information from students Surfdrive researchers involved in the study

physiological data: eye-tracking, galvanic skin sensor, heart rate 

 

 diverse formats diverse sources To collect information from students Surfdrive researchers involved in the study

questions.text: 4. How much data storage will you require during the project lifetime?
5. What documentation will accompany data?

answer.text:
1. Researchers will include the data collection methodology in their study proposals. Their publications will clearly detail the data collection and analysis methodology.

2. A text document containing all related information will be stored with the data, for example:

  • the creator, owner, location, date, license, location, size, and other general metadata
  • the purpose of the survey,
  • the context,
  • the type of participants,
  • the full text of the questions asked,
  • the meaning of used categories and used abbreviations
  • the measurement units for all (numerical) values
  • if the data is in table form, the meaning of each field

2. The data for each study will be stored in a single folder with separate files depending on the type of data collected. A naming convention has been devised for systematic retrieval:

study name_academic year_ quarter_course code_ variables_other details

 “learning strategies_20192020_Q3_CSE1200_exam grades.csv/xls”

 

Methodology file: process in which the data is collected

README file: we will follow the guidelines stated in https://data.4tu.nl/info/fileadmin/user_upload/Documenten/Guidelines_for_creating_a_README_file.pdf

options.text: README file or other documentation explaining how data is organised
Data will be deposited in a data repository at the end of the project (see section V) and data discoverability and re-usability will be ensured by adhering to the repository’s metadata standards

sections.title: III. Storage and backup during research process

questions.text: 6. Where will the data (and code, if applicable) be stored and backed-up during the project lifetime?

sections.title: IV. Legal and ethical requirements, codes of conduct

questions.text: 7. Does your research involve human subjects?

8A. Will you work with personal data?  (information about an identified or identifiable natural person)

If you are not sure which option to select, ask your Faculty Data Steward for advice. You can also check with the privacy website or contact the privacy team: privacy-tud@tudelft.nl

answer.text: refer to Question 10

questions.text:
8B. Will you work with any types of confidential or classified data or code as listed below? (tick all that apply)

If you are not sure which option to select, ask your Faculty Data Steward for advice.

answer.text: We will work with confidential data such as student grades, student numbers, personal information in OSIRIS (e.g., age, gender, educational background)

options.text: Yes, I work with other types of confidential or classified data (or code) - please explain below

questions.text:
9. How will ownership of the data and intellectual property rights to the data be managed?

For projects involving commercially-sensitive research or research involving third parties, seek advice of your Faculty Contract Manager when answering this question. If this is not the case, you can use the example below.

answer.text:
The data is owned by the TU Delft, and access is managed by the project leader.

The confidential data is stored locally and is only accessible by and limited to the researchers in PRIME research team. 

Researchers in charge of individual projects will create identifiers when anonymizing the data sets. The anonymized data will be in the repository.

questions.text: 10. Which personal data will you process? Tick all that apply

answer.text:
student interaction data in learning management systems (e.g., log file)

physiological data (e.g., eye-tracking, heart rate)

interview data (e.g., audio and video recordings)

options.text: Photographs, video materials, performance appraisals or student results
Special categories of personal data (specify which): race, ethnicity, criminal offence data, political beliefs, union membership, religion, sex life, health data, biometric or genetic data
Other types of personal data - please explain below
Access or identification details, such as personnel number, student number
Data collected in Informed Consent form (names and email addresses)
Gender, date of birth and/or age
Email addresses and/or other addresses for digital communication

questions.text: 11. Please list the categories of data subjects

answer.text:
stakeholders in PRIME (e.g., students, lecturers, faculty directors).

Any student under the age of 16 will not be part of our study.

questions.text: 12. Will you be sharing personal data with individuals/organisations outside of the EEA (European Economic Area)?
13. To which countries will you be transferring personal data:

14. Please contact the privacy team (privacy-tud@tudelft.nl) for advice on data transfer.

Please record below their advice, the data transfer mechanism used and agreed security measures:
15. What is the legal ground for personal data processing?

answer.text: The privacy team has stated that a DPIA is not necessary.

options.text: Other - please explain and contact the privacy team (privacy-tud@tudelft.nl). If you have already contacted the privacy team and received their advice, please record their advice below

questions.text: 16. Please describe the informed consent procedure you will follow:

answer.text:
Students will be asked to provide their informed consent at the beginning of each study. 

The informed consent will include:

  • Purpose of the research
  • Benefits and risks of participating
  • Procedures for withdrawal from the study
  • Whether any personal information about the participant will be collected, processed, and how and for what purpose; the right of the participant to request access to and rectification or erasure of personal data. The participant can request to be excluded from video or audio.
  • Usage of the data during research, safeguarding personal information, maintaining confidentiality and de-identifying (anonymising) data, controlled access to data, especially in relation to data archiving and reuse, ways of dissemination, data archiving and possible publishing
  • Retention period for the research data, or if that is not possible, criteria used to determine that period
  • Contact details of the researcher (or his/her representative), contact details of the data protection officer, institution, funding source, how to file a complaint.

 

An example of informed consent (from previous PRIME DMP):

 

Dear student,

We would like to inform you about research in Quarter 3 on learning from online videos and ask you for your co-operation in this research. The goal of the research is to improve learning from the pre-lecture activities. In order to investigate this, you will first be asked to participate and give informed consent at the start of the course. Subsequently, you will be given a short questionnaire at the start and at the end of the course. During the course, you will be quizzed about the pre-lecture content during the lectures, as usual.

For this research, data will be collected from the online environment (Brightspace), quizzes in the lectures, and achievements on the exams. This data will be anonymized and will only be accessible to the researchers. The choice to participate in this research will not affect the assessments of this course in any way.

We are sure that there are no risks in participation in this research. However, in research situations, misuse is always a possibility. That is why we assure the participants that we will do everything that lies in our possibilities to ensure the confidentiality of the answers. To minimize risks we shall replace the student numbers with other numbers that will not be traceable to individual students as a person when all relevant data will be processed. This ensures and guarantees anonymity.

Data files will be kept until then in a safe data site and approved by the ethical committee. Finally, the anonymous data will be available open-source in the Dataverse repository of LDE CEL (TU Delft, Erasmus University Rotterdam, Leiden University). When you don’t want your data to be stored on that site, please send an email to  [researcher] before the end of April 2019 in which case she can remove your data before it will be anonymized and stored in the repository.

For questions about this study, please contact [name of researcher], email of researcher

Thank you for your cooperation,

names of researchers

questions.text: 17. Where will you store the signed consent forms?

options.text: Same storage solutions as explained in question 6

questions.text:
18. Does the processing of the personal data result in a high risk to the data subjects? 

If the processing of the personal data results in a high risk to the data subjects, it is required to perform a Data Protection Impact Assessment (DPIA). In order to determine if there is a high risk for the data subjects, please check if any of the options below that are applicable to the processing of the personal data during your research (check all that apply).

If two or more of the options listed below apply, you will have to complete the DPIA. Please get in touch with the privacy team: privacy-tud@tudelft.nl to receive support with DPIA.
If only one of the options listed below applies, your project might need a DPIA. Please get in touch with the privacy team: privacy-tud@tudelft.nl to get advice as to whether DPIA is necessary.

If you have any additional comments, please add them in the box below.

answer.text:
Predictive analytics will be made on aggregated anonymized data. 

For some studies, we will combine data sets involving academic grades and surveys. 

The privacy team has stated that a DPIA is not necessary, after assessing this DMP.

options.text: Innovative use or applying new technological or organisational solutions for data processing

questions.text: 19. Did the privacy team advise you to perform a DPIA?
20. Please include below the outcome of the DPIA, what measures did you take?
21. Where will you store the DPIA documents (document on data processing features and document on risk assessment)?
22. What will happen with personal research data after the end of the research project?

answer.text: Please refer to informed consent.

options.text: Personal data will be shared with others - please explain which personal data will be shared, with whom, how and whether you have specified this in the informed consent form
Anonymised or aggregated data will be shared with others

questions.text: 23. How long will (pseudonymised) personal data be stored for?

answer.text: We shall use a key to pseudonomised personal data. This key stays within the project team. When information is shared outside the project team, it will be irreversible and not traceable, so data is then anonymised.

options.text: 10 years or more, in accordance with the TU Delft Research Data Framework Policy

questions.text: 24. What is the purpose of sharing personal data?

options.text: For research purposes, which are in-line with the original research purpose for which data have been collected

questions.text: 25. Will your study participants be asked for their consent for data sharing?

answer.text: Data of participants who did not consent to data sharing will be removed from the final data set that will be shared.

options.text: Yes, in consent form - please explain below what will do with data from participants who did not consent to data sharing

sections.title: V. Data sharing and long-term preservation

questions.text: 26. What data will be publicly shared?

answer.text: Data and code will be shared after ensuring that the data are properly anonymized.

options.text: All data (and code) underlying published articles / reports / theses

questions.text: 27. Apart from personal data mentioned in question 22, will any other data be publicly shared?

options.text: All other non-personal data (and code) produced in the project
All other non-personal data (and code) underlying published articles / reports / theses

questions.text: 28. How will you share your research data (and code)?
29. How will you share research data (and code), including the one mentioned in question 22?

options.text: All anonymised or aggregated data, and/or all other non-personal data will be uploaded to 4TU.ResearchData with public access

questions.text: 30. How much of your data will be shared in a research data repository?
31. When will the data (or code) be shared?

options.text: As soon as corresponding results (papers, theses, reports) are published

questions.text: 32. Under what licence will be the data/code released?

sections.title: VI. Data management responsibilities and resources

questions.text: 33. Is TU Delft the lead institution for this project?
34. If you leave TU Delft (or are unavailable), who is going to be responsible for the data resulting from this project?

answer.text: The person who takes over the project lead of PRIME.

questions.text: 35. What resources (for example financial and time) will be dedicated to data management and ensuring that data will be FAIR (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, Re-usable)?

answer.text: 4TU.ResearchData is able to archive 1TB of data per researcher per year free of charge for all TU Delft researchers. We do not expect to exceed this and therefore there are no additional costs of long-term preservation.

plan_content.title: Initial DMP
plan_content.description:
Once a project has had its funding approved and has started, you must submit a first  version of your DMP (as a deliverable) within the first 6 months of the project. The Commission provides a DMP template, the use of which is recommended but voluntary. That template has been replicated by the UK Digital Curation Centre for use in DMPonline.

It is not required to provide detailed answers to all the questions in the first version of the DMP that needs to be submitted by month 6 of the project. Rather, the DMP is intended to be a living document in which information can be made available on a finer level of granularity through updates as the implementation of the project progresses and when significant changes occur. Therefore, DMPs should have a clear version number and include a timetable for updates.

questions.text:
Provide a summary of the data addressing the following issues:

  • State the purpose of the data collection/generation
  • Explain the relation to the objectives of the project
  • Specify the types and formats of data generated/collected
  • Specify if existing data is being re-used (if any)
  • Specify the origin of the data
  • State the expected size of the data (if known)
  • Outline the data utility: to whom will it be useful

sections.title: 2. FAIR data
sections.description: In general terms, your research data should be 'FAIR' that is findable, accessible, interoperable and re-usable. These principles precede implementation choices and do not necessarily suggest any specific technology, standard or implementation-solution.

questions.text:
2.1 Making data findable, including provisions for metadata:

  • Outline the discoverability of data (metadata provision)
  • Outline the identifiability of data and refer to standard identification mechanism. Do you make use of persistent and unique identifiers such as Digital Object Identifiers?
  • Outline naming conventions used
  • Outline the approach towards search keyword
  • Outline the approach for clear versioning
  • Specify standards for metadata creation (if any). If there are no standards in your discipline describe what metadata will be created and how

2.2 Making data openly accessible:

  • Specify which data will be made openly available? If some data is kept closed provide rationale for doing so
  • Specify how the data will be made available
  • Specify what methods or software tools are needed to access the data? Is documentation about the software needed to access the data included? Is it possible to include the relevant software (e.g. in open source code)?
  • Specify where the data and associated metadata, documentation and code are deposited
  • Specify how access will be provided in case there are any restrictions

2.3 Making data interoperable:

  • Assess the interoperability of your data. Specify what data and metadata vocabularies, standards or methodologies you will follow to facilitate interoperability.
  • Specify whether you will be using standard vocabulary for all data types present in your data set, to allow inter-disciplinary interoperability? If not, will you provide mapping to more commonly used ontologies?

2.4 Increase data re-use (through clarifying licenses):

  • Specify how the data will be licenced to permit the widest reuse possible
  • Specify when the data will be made available for re-use. If applicable, specify why and for what period a data embargo is needed
  • Specify whether the data produced and/or used in the project is useable by third parties, in particular after the end of the project? If the re-use of some data is restricted, explain why
  • Describe data quality assurance processes
  • Specify the length of time for which the data will remain re-usable

Explain the allocation of resources, addressing the following issues:

  • Estimate the costs for making your data FAIR. Describe how you intend to cover these costs
  • Clearly identify responsibilities for data management in your project
  • Describe costs and potential value of long term preservation
Address data recovery as well as secure storage and transfer of sensitive data
To be covered in the context of the ethics review, ethics section of DoA and ethics deliverables. Include references and related technical aspects if not covered by the former
Refer to other national/funder/sectorial/departmental procedures for data management that you are using (if any)

plan_content.title: Detailed DMP
plan_content.description:
The DMP is intended to be a living document in which information can be made available on a finer level of granularity through updates as the implementation of the project progresses.

The DMP needs to be updated over the course of the project whenever significant changes arise, such as (but not limited to):

  • new data
  • changes in consortium policies (e.g. new innovation potential, decision to file for a patent)
  • changes in consortium composition and external factors (e.g. new consortium members joining or old members leaving)

plan_content.title: Final review DMP
plan_content.description: The DMP should be updated as a minimum in time with the periodic evaluation/assessment of the project. If there are no other periodic reviews foreseen within the grant agreement, then such an update needs to be made in time for the final review at the latest.
